text: I believe React is often overkill and diminishes the one thing most websites aim to maximize, their SEO. React is best for highly reactive single page applications, utilizing the virtual DOM to manage user interactions and changing state efficiently. It isn't as strong when it comes to static page generation, where content changes slowly over time, the exception being tools like Remix or NextJS. However, HubSpot has several tools to help collect and organize metrics and inbound requests, including forms, CTAs, drag-and-drop modules, custom templates, local development via the CLI + Webpack plugins, user data metrics and dashboards. Blog posts and listings are built with templates that are fully customizable, as well. I develop my sites with TypeScript and a few small libraries, while leveraging as much of HubSpot's tooling to minimize the work I have to do maintaining the code. If you're set on using React for parts of your site, you may want to consider Preact's smaller footprint.

Oeps, never mind! Read it more carefully now and I assume you are using the HS CLI and use typescript when building your website locally.

I enjoy the benefits of an all-in-one solution for the backend and information aspects of websites, though I come from a background using full-stack frameworks to manage all parts myself - sounds like you do, too. The most difficult part with standard HS development is relying on HS to display your code updates. This can be mitigated by moving to things like web components and building those in a highly reactive way before connecting them to the HubSpot layer.
